comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content:
From 1897. Could there be a more (stereo-) typical motive of Napoli? (Actually there is, the print number 9997 shows a spaghetti-eating competition...)
 
This should probably better be translated as "Macaroni eaters".

comment.author: 33572458@N05
comment._content: ...trialsanderrors noticed that we accidentally reposted this image later in our photostream.

comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: No problem, Phil, I can have many more servings of these prints. Just wanted to make sure you're not losing the information from the prior postings...

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Phil, if you're going to give us a double helping of Mac, don't forget the Cheddar on top!

comment.author: 73087214@N00
comment._content:
Penso che il titolo corretto sia "Mangiatori di spaghetti". Primo perché si tratta di spaghetti, non di maccheroni (cosi detti maccaroni all'americana). Secondo non mi pare che abbiano un banco di vendita, piuttosto un bel piatto dove mangiare. Ed è quindi logico immaginare che questo ritratto sia una scherzosa parodia del ben più famoso quadro fiammingo "Mangiatori di patate". 
Se avete voglia traducete voi il mio commento in inglese. Grazie, Buona giornata.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content:
This is what Bing translator came up with:
I think the correct title is "spaghetti eaters". First because it's spaghetti, not Macaroni (so called American maccaroni). 2nd I do not think that they have a sales counter, rather a dish to eat. And it is therefore logical to imagine that this picture is a playful parody of the much more famous painting Dutch "potato eaters".
If you fancy you translate my comment in English. Thanks, have a nice day.

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: The original caption of the photochrome is „NAPOLI . MACCHERONAIO“. It seems, that the maccheronaio was a popular topic on postcards from naples at that time, showing people producing, selling or eating pasta. The maccheroni look always like spaghetti or bucatini today, see the following examples:
